instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message: This came in with no spill, with a swollen battery and 5V on USB. I'm not finding any shorts. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 0V. No short. <SIGNAL>PM_EN_PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 0V. Diode measurement is good at .580. Is this just a damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message:
Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
Post <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> voltages.

Compare diode mode readings on the power rails of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message:
After sitting for weeks, the first time I plugged it in, it went up to 20V and the CPU heated up. By the time I started testing for voltage is was back down to 5V.

<CHIP>U6903</CHIP> Voltages:
1 0
2 5V
3 0
4 0
5 0
6 0
7 0
8 0
9 0
10 0

Pins 1 and 8 had some very small amount of varying voltage.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_X_USBC</SIGNAL> is measuring around .160 in diode mode whereas <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_T_USBC</SIGNAL> is measuring .220 and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_X_USBC</SIGNAL> on a good board I have measures .220. Not sure it that would be enough to be concerning but that?s the only difference I can find in diode mode on the power lines around the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message:
I was thinking about LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

"<CHIP>U6903</CHIP> Voltages:
-------
10 0"
<RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR> is OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message:
LDO's are all at .495.
<RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR> is good at 0 ohms. <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message:
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> has 3 types of LDO outputs; 1.1V, 1.8V and 3.3V.
I doubt you get exactly same 495 value on all.

Looks like <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> issue.
Check first <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>/P.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message:
Ok, got it, didn't realize there were so many. I checked the other LDO outputs. They're the same for each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. .480 .470 and .495. No outliers.

<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> is at 1.28 V and <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>/P are at 2.3V. After letting it sit overnight, it did go back up to 20V again the first time I plugged it in. No current though. <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>/P were at 5V when it first turned on with 20V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No spill, swollen battery 5V on USB
threads.message: Thanks, got it, replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Ended up just being that after all.
